_prev_prog_3.Description:
The storage and dispensing of acrylonitrile (AN) is to be considered as one unit. The system is under construction with completion anticipated by late January 2006. The system consists of a truck unloading area, 20,000 gallon AN storage tank, a portable tank filling station and an emergency vent scrubbing system.  All of these are in secondary containment areas.

To date the following programs and procedures have been developed: Company Safety Program, Emergency Response Plan, Spill Plan, Sequence of Operations for all major components, Preventive Maintenance Program, Lockout/Tagout Program, Process Hazard Analysis, Process Equipment Mechanical Integrity review, Operator Training Programs and a Pre-startup Review Program.

Prior to startup, process operators will receive safety and operations training and the pre-startup check will have been completed.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary
Absorbent Technologies, Inc Manufacturing Facility
140 Queen Avenue, SW

Introduction
Absorbent Technologies, Inc. (ATI), based in Beaverton, Ore., develops and manufactures starch-based soil amendments (Zeba brand) that help improve plant and crop quality and yield for the agriculture and nursery industry, with less water and more efficient use of other inputs. When introduced into the soil, Zeba products absorb a tremendous amount of water and slowly releases over a long period of time.
 
Between 1996 and 2002, ATI conducted an extensive research program to develop the starch-based polymers technologies.  During 2003, ATI opened up the Product Development Center located at 2830 Ferry Avenue, SW, Albany, Oregon. This pilot plant conducted runs to further refine the process. This facility is still in operation to further refine the process. During 2004, ATI started construction of a full scale manufacturing facility located at 140 Queen Avenue, SW, Albany, Oregon, which is the site this RPM is being developed for. In 2009 ATI finished construction on the front-end process at the full scale manufacturing facility developing starch-based co-polymer. Construction of the tail-end "dewatering" process is scheduled for 1st quarter 2010.
 
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Absorbent Technologies, Inc. is committed to the safety of its workers and the public along with the preservation of the environment through the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances. It was ATI's philosophy to design the acrylonitrile (AN) storage and dispensing system with the latest in control systems, secondary containment enclosures and scrubbing systems. In addition to these mechanical prevention measures, ATI has operator training programs, preventative maintenance procedures and programs to evaluate hazards.

In the unlikely event of an accidental release, ATI has included secondary containment systems that that would contain a liq

uid AN release and allow emergency response teams to safely remove the spilled material. A vapor release of AN from a valve or pump leak will be captured in one of six exhausted enclosures that are ducted to two scrubbers. A large spill in the secondary containment area would be blanketed with foam to greatly reduce evaporation.

ATI provides emergency response training to all plant personnel, has a designated emergency response coordinator to oversee response activities and coordinate response efforts with response contractors and the local fire department.

In order to implement these policies, ATI has established a management system directed by ATI's President & Chief Executive Officer.

 
Facility and Regulated Substances
The regulated substance will be acrylonitrile (AN). It is used for manufacturing at the facilities located at 140 Queen Avenue, SW and 2830 Ferry Street, SW. The first phase in the construction of the manufacturing facility, completed January 2006, was the installation of a 20,000-gallon AN storage tank, AN truck unloading area and portable AN tank filling station. 40 CFR Part 68 lists the threshold quantity for acrylonitrile at 20,000 pounds. The AN storage tank, at times, contains over 135,000 pounds of AN thereby triggering the original development of this Risk Management Plan.  ATI receives periodic tanker truck deliveries to the 20,000-gallon storage tank. ATI then fills 260-gallon portable tanks that will be transferred to Product Development Center for use in the Pilot Plant. 

Phase Two was the construction of the front-end of the manufacturing process at the Queen Avenue facility, completed October 2009. During this step of manufacturing process, AN is mixed with a starch/water solution and pumped to the graft reactor.  The material goes to a blender where the starch and all of the AN is transformed into a co-polymer called "dough". The dough is then be transported to the Product Development Center to be processed into a finished produ

ct. Development and construction of the co-polymer production line added a process in which the acrylonitrile was involved, triggering a addition and resubmission to the Risk Management Plan at this facility.

The RMP currently covers all Phase 1 and Phase 2 operations involving acrylonitrile.

Phase Three will be the installation of the second stage processing equipment. The schedule for the completion of this phase has not yet been established at this time. This phase will not require any modifications to the RMP as there is no acrylontirile involved in these processes.


Accidential Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps 
The design of the acrylonitrile (AN) storage tank, piping systems and portable tank filling system was developed with safety as the top priority. The tanker truck is top unloaded and all the piping is double walled. The hose connections are the DryLoc and CamLoc types to prevent spills. The storage tank is double walled protected tank, which means it is bulletproof. There are no valves on the tank that are located below the liquid level. The tank vent is routed back to the top of the truck, which also would be the route if the tank were to be overfilled. The tank has over pressure relief valves, which vent to a carbon scrubber. The tanker truck unloading area has secondary containment that will hold the contents of the truck. There is also a sump in the containment area that contains a high volume pump that will transfer spilled AN to an emergency holding tank. The sump is also connected to the secondary containment for the storage tank. There is also an emergency generator that will supply power to the controls, alarms and pumps in the event of a power failure.

Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specification Prevention Steps:

The design of the acrylonitrile (AN) storage tank, piping systems, pump house, graft reactor and portable tank filling system were all developed with safety as the top priority

. The tanker truck is top unloaded and all the piping is double walled. The hose connections are the DryLoc and CamLoc types to prevent spills. The storage tank is double walled and no valves are located below the liquid level. The tank vent is routed back to the top of the truck during filling, which also would the route in the event the tank was overfilled. The storage tank also has over pressure valves, which vent to a carbon scrubber. The tanker truck unloading area has secondary containment that will hold the entire contents of the truck. There is also a sump in all the tank secondary containment areas to contain releases. In the event of a high volume release the contents of the secondary containment can be pumped into one of two emergency holding tanks. There is an emergency generator that will power the controls, alarms, and pumps in the event of a power failure. 

All pumps, mixers, and valves are located in one of the seven ventilated enclosures, all located within the secondary containment. AN vapor sensors are located in the enclosures exhaust ducting, which will quickly detect a leak, stop all pumping, and sound an alarm. All of these enclosures are vented back to the carbon scrubber. All tanks, pipes, valves, enclosures and pumps are within the 38,000-gallon concrete containment area. All tanks are equipped with level gauges and high level alarms. There are several fire detection sensors located throughout the containment area that will activate a foam suppression system. This system will not only extinguish a fire but will also inhibit the vaporization of the AN. 

Prior to filling the portable tank, they are placed inside an enclosure that has secondary containment and is exhausted to the carbon scrubber. The portable tanks are double walled and do not have valves below the liquid level. The vent from the portable tank is piped back into the top of the storage tank to prevent vapor loses. Any overfilling of the portable tanks would be returned back t

he to storage tank.

Five Year Accident History:

Since brining acrylonitrile (AN) on-site January 2006 there have been no reportable injuries that were the result of AN exposure.

Emergency Response Program:

ATI has a written Emergency Action Plan in place. It lists the various types of emergencies and the responsibilities of plant personnel. The plan includes: 
A?    Who the emergency coordinators and team members are
A?    24-hour contact telephone numbers
A?    Contract emergency responders for clean-up
A?    Controlling and containing procedures in incidental releases
A?    Procedures for updating and reviewing the emergency action plan.
The written emergency response plan also complies with OSHAA?s Emergency Action Plan requirements (29 CFR 1910.38). The emergency response plan has been communicated to the local Fire Marshal.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

ATI constantly strives to improve the safety of the production activities by utilizing knowledge gained from the operation of the Product Development Center located in Albany, Oregon.

ATI employs a full time Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) professional to oversee the environmental and safety needs of the company and itA?s employees. Among the EHS job functions is Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) of operations and procedures. PHAs have been documented for the AN storage and dispensing systems as well as the AN manufacturing process. PHAs will be reviewed, updated and added to when an operation or procedure changes or on an annual basis (whichever occurs first). Team PHA review has occurred throughout our construction process and additions involving the use or storage of AN are documented in this RMP. Operator and emergency responder training occurs on an annual basis or at hire date of new employee.
